label: Blink
info: Multiple ways to blink an LED. Or blink (toggle) a dashboard element.

label: Multiple LEDs
info: The blink tab explores multiple ways of controlling the state of a single output (LED). It shows that it is easy to independently control multiple LEDs. It is only necessary to write a new flow for each output to be controlled. This tab explores methods of synchronously controlling multiple outputs.

name: simLED
info:
Simulated single LED using a dashboard text node. Internally this controls the state by setting the text content colour to the defined "On" and "Off" colors, based on a boolean input payload value.

Uses flow.ON_COLOUR and flow.OFF_COLOUR context properties.

name: simpLED
info: Simple LED simulation, turned "on" and "off" using true and false payloads

name: delTrueFalse
info: Wait msg.delay (or 50) milliseconds, then send separate true and false messages

name: Blink 1
info: A structure very similar to the Arduino Blink sketch, with individual delays after each state change. There is not pin number here. The LED is simulated by a dashboard text element that has an "O" value with the color being toggled by the blink state.

name: Blink 2
info: Use a trigger node to generate a (logical) high and low pulse. The "On" time is controlled by the delay configured in the trigger node, instead of needed a separate delay. That does mean that something else (the switch node) is needed to actually set the output colour value.

name: Blink 3
info:
Instead of 'looping', take advantage of the repeating event capability of the inject node. Set it to repeat every on time + off time length.

Likely unexpected results will be obtained if the interval is less than the configured on time in the trigger node.

name: Blink 4
info: Use the basic delay loop structure, but store information in flow (context) variables. The speed and colors can all be adjusted by changing values in the "Setup" node.

name: Blink On
info: Set the "LED" colour, and delay time for the "ON" state

name: Blink Off
info: Set the "LED" colour, and delay time for the "OFF" state

name: Blink 5
info: Use flow context values (variables) that can be adjusted from the dashboard will the flow is running

name: Led Sequencer
Set State Colour
info: Use JSONata ternary operator to select the source for the colour value from that available (subflow) properties.

name: Sequence Stepper
info: Use a delay, instead of just an injection node configured for repeat, because the incection repeat is in seconds, not milliseconds

name: Function Sequence
info:
This structure dastically simplifies the flow, but needs a function to implement the desired pattern. The function is not large, but could be finicky to get all of the cases right.

This flow also looses the ability to set the LED state colors by external commands. That has nothing to do with the flow structure itself. The limit is on the simpler subflow used to implement the simulated LED. The advantage being that no run time initialization of the LEDs is needed.

name: Indiviual steps
info: Turn on each LED in sequence, until they are all on, then reverse the sequence until they are all off. This uses basic nodes in a sequence, effectively a clocked state machine. This makes for a lot of connected nodes, though the pattern is simple.

name: One at a time
info:
Turn one LED on at time, turning it off again when turning on the next LED. Each step turns off one LED and turns on another.

To keep the pattern of wires simple, link nodes are used to wrap from the bottom to the top.

name: One at a time
info: Refactor a common section to a subflow, simplifying the pattern

name: In And Out
info: The logic is simple enough. Starting from the middle, turn on 2 leds. Next step, move outward, turnning on the next 2 LEDS. Repeat until the outer 2 LEDs are on, then reverse until the centre 2 are on. At each step, turn off the leds that were turned on in the previous step. That means that each step manipulates the state of 4 LEDS, which makes for a lot of connections between nodes.

name: In And Out
info: In and out with simplified flow, by noticing that the LEDs are always manipulated in pairs. The same 2 are always turned on or off together. Group those together, so only a single message wire is needed to trigger the state change.

name: Blink 6
info:
The injection node can be configured to repeat a message at a specified interval. The smallest units for the interval are seconds, but fractional values work fine. 0.5 seconds instead of 500 milliseconds.  The trigger node sends 2 distinct messages with a configurable interval between them.  Those 2 combined create a complete blink pattern. The injection interval is the time for the complete cylcle (on and off times), the trigger delay in the on time.

The trigger node is set to issue "on" and "off" messages. In this setup, than means to send "red" and "white" colors. The content of the trigger message is always/only in the payload, so the simulated LED needs to listen for it there, instead of in the msg.color value used earlier.

name: Blink 7
info: Borrowing the logic from the "simple LED" subflow created while working on the multiple LEDs example flows, the trigger node from the "Blink 6" example can be changed to output the more generic boolean "true" for on, and "false" for off payload values. This matches what a real switchable LED (Hooked to an Arduino digital output pin) would expect. The LED knows what the on and off colour values are. The blink just tells it to use them.

name: Set State Colour
info: Use JSONata ternary operator to select the source for the colour value from that available (subflow) properties.

name: Wait Init
info: Wait until all of the inialization has finished

name: Default Values
info: Initialize the values to use when flow starts

name: Dashboard Controls
info: Set of controls (on Dashboard) to change the configuration settings while the flow is running

name: Save Changes
info: Save any configuration settings that have been changed on the Dashboard

name: Standard Blink
info: A version of the regular blink flow, but using values colour and time values from the stored flow context
